title: I'm not being able to understand this sentence - 'I allowed myself to be persuaded into entering the competition.' does this mean - 'I persuaded myself into entering the competition.' or 'Someone persuaded me to enter the competition.'? - Quora

response.answer_text: The phrase or sentence, “I persuaded myself into entering the competition.”, works well in English, and probably means the latter alternative, “'Someone persuaded me to enter the competition.” It’s a peculiar phraseology usually used by people to mean, “against my better judgment, and without adequate care for the consequences, I….” In short, whenever you come across this phrase, the writer is telling you that he/she made a bad decision, but you shouldn’t hold it against him/her TOO much.

First of all the sentence ”I allowed myself to be persuaded into entering the competition.” is grammatically not correct, and it should be “ I allowed myself to be persuaded to enter into the competition.” When one allows herself to be persuaded, it is mean there is someone who is persuading. So there is no occasion for the one to persuade herself when she is already being persuaded by someone else. Hope it clarifies the confusion.
